column10:
What I remember and cherish the most about Fulbright is that it’s where I got lost and found myself. For almost three years, I didn’t really know what I was doing here. I came in wanting to study psychology to help people. But the psychology classes I took didn’t give me the feeling that I was actually learning how to do that. I studied a lot, learned a ton across different subjects - but still felt lost. People would come to me with their problems, and even with everything I knew, I couldn’t really help them.

Then I joined the Person-Centered Counseling class, and it completely changed everything. There, I learned how to talk to people, how to reflect their emotions, how to affirm their strengths, and how to provide information and inspire hope. After that, everything just started to make sense. I finally had a channel - a way to put what I’d learned into practice. I felt reborn and motivated. In some way, the class inspired me just like how it taught me to inspire people, and I think that’s - very cool.
column11:
When I started at Fulbright, I was just kind of... lost. I came in straight from high school, where I didn’t try very hard. I didn’t think I was smart. I didn’t think I was anything, really. Most of my time was spent gaming, staying inside, avoiding stuff. I was passive, quiet, and honestly didn’t know how to handle life. I wasn’t miserable, but I wasn’t doing great either.

At Fulbright, everything hit me fast. The workload, the expectations, the people who actually knew what they were doing. I had no clue how to keep up. Classes were tough. Juggling readings, chores, gym, food - it was a lot. I got overwhelmed. A lot. But I kept pushing through, even when I felt like I was drowning.

There wasn’t a single “aha” moment for me - it was more like a slow, messy climb. Every semester I learned a little more, failed a little less. I started showing up to class prepared. I joined conversations. I asked questions. Sometimes I even had answers. I started seeing myself differently—not as someone who’s just trying to keep up, but as someone who actually belongs here.

And somewhere in the middle of all this, I stopped hiding. I started making friends. Talking to people. Being present. Not perfectly, not all at once - but enough to notice the difference. I even started helping others with their own stuff, using what I’d learned. That part still surprises me sometimes.

I’m still figuring things out. I still want to be a counselor, and now that dream feels a little more real. I have a long way to go, but at least now I’m walking in the right direction.

To my parents - thank you. I don’t say it enough, but I love you. Everything I’ve done here, I owe to your support and belief in me. I’m going to try my best to make you proud.

Fulbright wasn’t just a place I studied - it was the place I grew up. Slowly. Awkwardly. But honestly. And that’s what I’ll remember most.

I still remember the moment I realized just how much I wanted to become a part of the Fulbright family, I kept circling around the question, “Why Fulbright?” It echoed in my mind until I finally started taking the idea seriously. I looked back at my journey—the things I’d done, the moments that shaped me, the passions I had for baking and hospitality. And the more I reflected, the more certain I became: I didn’t just want to go to Fulbright—I needed to. Fulbright woke something up in me from the very beginning. For the first time, I felt that my individuality, my story, and even the “unconventional” parts of me were not only accepted but celebrated. Where others once said baking or extracurriculars were a waste of time, Fulbright said they mattered. Fulbright said I mattered.

After four years, what I hold most dearly from my time here is the gift of self-agency and reflection. Fulbright taught me how to pause, look inward, and face the uncertainty of the world around me. I’ve learned that it’s okay not to have all the answers, that growth often begins in discomfort. I won't say I’ve stopped avoiding hard truths altogether—but I have learned to be more open, to meet challenges with a realistic yet kinder view of myself. I’ve learned how to listen—not just to others, but to what’s happening inside me.
Looking ahead, I want to keep creating—with my hands, my words, and my choices. I want to build a life where authenticity, care, and curiosity guide me. I want to keep showing up, even when things are messy, even when I’m unsure.

To every beautiful soul I’ve met at Fulbright—thank you. You’ve shaped my journey in ways words can hardly capture and reminded me, time and time again, why choosing Fulbright was the best decision I’ve ever made.

To my very first house, 133A—you were my shelter, my laughter, my late-night talks, my home. To CIDO club, where I found not just a place to belong, but a place to lead, to learn, and to grow. To đại đội 6, thank you for being my steady ground and for supporting me so wholeheartedly during those early days when I was still learning what it meant to lead. To all my professors who gave so generously of their time, patience, and wisdom—thank you for seeing me, for believing in me, even when I was still learning how to believe in myself.

And above all, to cô Nga, thầy Matthew, and thầy Tony—my deepest love and gratitude. You didn’t just teach me; you transformed me. Your kindness, brilliance, and belief in me anchored me through my most uncertain moments. Because of you, I walk forward not just with knowledge, but with purpose, courage, and heart.

If I had to choose one memory to hold onto forever from Fulbright, it would be Universe Dance Competition 2023 with The Luminous. We weren’t just a dance team - we were a chaotic, loving, resilient little family. We practiced like crazy for three months. Late nights, sore bodies, missed meals, endless run-throughs. There were moments we cried, shouted at each other, felt like quitting. But somehow, we always came back - because we believed in what we were building.

Exactly 14 of us, and our team “mommy” anh Nguyen, stood on that stage, hearts pounding, hands shaking, but eyes locked on the same dream. It was my last UDC, our second time representing Fulbright, and we gave it everything. Every time I rewatch the video or see a behind-the-scenes moment, I tear up. Not because it was perfect, but because we made it through, together. That experience taught me how beautiful it is to work hard for something you love, with people you love, even when it’s tough. From that journey, I learned what it really means to be resilient, sympathetic, and goal-oriented. And most of all, I learned how powerful it is to not give up on each other.

From panic to peace (rollercoaster - this is the same theme as my Essay applied to Fulbright)

I still remember when I was that girl with a clear path: study biology, get into med school, save lives. Period. But then boom - a plot twist. Somehow, I ended up here, at Fulbright. The first few months in Saigon were intense. I had a major culture and mentality shock. Fulbright was exciting but terrifying at the same time. I was still this chaotic girl who wanted to do everything all at once, with no clear priorities. I got all at once (debate, dance, investment, social enterprise, etc.), which was a truly a chaotic starting point. It was messy. I was overwhelmed. 

But slowly, it got better - because of people. Lan Thanh, Thuy An, Phuong Linh, Tu Linh… thank you for being the calm in my storm. You reminded me that I wasn’t alone. You were there through the breakdowns, the breakthroughs, the all-nighters, and the silly laughs. I’m so lucky to have found you all. I should reward them as my beloved anchor, my late-night ramen buddies, my reality checks, and my hype squad.

Things truly began to shift in my third and final year. That was when Computer Science entered the picture. A huge shoutout to thầy Đăng - he’s the reason I found a passion for data and tech. I used to doubt him when he said things like, “Cái này chắc chắn có trong vòng phỏng vấn BA, DA, v, đó các em,” but he was so right. Those exact questions popped up in my real interviews. So to my juniors from Co26, Co27, Co28... just trust thầy Đăng, okay?

And then there’s cô My. I wish I had met her earlier. She’s been like a big sister to me, both in terms of knowledge and emotional support. She’s been like a big sis, a mentor, and my favorite “partner in crime.” From casual conversation to deep life talks, she gave me both brain boosts and emotional support. Love you so much!

This final year was also the first time in two years that I didn’t take on an internship. I dedicated all my time to studying, and it changed everything. My mental health improved, and I felt more connected to the university community than ever before. Big hugs to everyone who screamed my name when I got into the final round of Ứng viên tài năng, and to those who believed in me even when I doubted myself during the job hunt.

So here it is - my last word. Of course I had moments I hated. The panic. The stress. The nights I cried over broken code and broken dreams. But if you ask me if I’d do it all again… yes. No regrets. Fulbright wasn’t just a university. It was a turning point in my life. And I’m proud of the person I’ve become here.

That moment, among countless I have had during my four years at Fulbright, embodies more than just normal chit chat conversations. It is the meaning of this university, and the meaning of going to a university in general. It is the conversation of those, for the past four years, sheltered away to think, to read, and to discuss with such liberty. Of course, it might not be the only time in our life that such conversations were possible, but I believe it would never be the same conversation when we were in our 20s. 

Moments like these. It made us who we are. Perhaps, we might only live these moments for once. The conversations in our young 20s were never perfect, because they never needed to be. It was random and messy. It was out of nowhere. And it was in Circle K. At midnight. For no reasons. Perhaps, it’s all we need for memorable 20s.

When I first stepped into Fulbright, I had no idea how deeply it would shape me. I was just another freshman - quietly observing, unsure of how I’d fit in. Now, looking back, I see a journey filled with growth, inspiration, and moments I’ll carry with me forever.

My Fulbright story began in an unusual way - online, during my first semester amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Everything was new: teaching methods, professors, and even friends I could count on one hand. I was overwhelmed, constantly wondering if I could keep up. But gradually, I learned to unmute myself, to speak up, and to reach out for help. That lonely start taught me resilience and made me appreciate in-person connection even more deeply when it finally arrived.

One of the first milestones that changed me was Fulbright Leadership Camp 2023. It was more than a camp - it was a space for self-discovery. I met people who dreamed boldly, cared deeply, and inspired me to do the same. We danced, debated, and connected in ways that reminded me of the power of community.

Later, I returned to a class I once loved - Digital Marketing with Professor Willem - this time as a Teaching Assistant. I helped organize the Hackathon, worked closely with students and businesses, and saw how learning can bridge into real-world impact. Thank you, Prof. Willem, for believing in me. That experience solidified my passion for education, mentorship, and creating empowering spaces.

Life used to feel like a storm I couldn’t escape. High school left me with too many wounds—being bullied, being afraid to perform even in what I was best at, and being laughed at for dreaming of a place where people value each other for who they are, not just grades. I thought that kind of environment only existed in fiction. My world was too small to believe otherwise.

Then Fulbright happened.

To some, it’s just a university. But for me, it was the miracle that opened a door to the life I never dared to imagine. I wasn’t the best student, but I became something more—I found pieces of myself I never knew were there. I realized I’m more than a number or a GPA. I’m someone with value, voice, and worth.

At Fulbright, I found people who reminded me that kindness and hope still exist. I found a place where I had the right to grow, to explore, and to become. Most importantly, I learned that I deserve that. I’m capable of creating such spaces for others too. That’s why I poured my heart into DAM, a project to help students break free from the bystander effect in bullying—something I once wished I had.

In four years, I lived many lives: an art student, a marketing lover, a neuroscience nerd, and a baby product manager. I realized I could be many things, as long as I followed what I truly love. And somewhere in between… I met your dad? (Yes, future kid. If it didn’t turn out that way… well, just skip this part) A hot nerd who plays guitar and appreciates art—am I in a shoujo anime?! He doesn’t always get my full Scorpio rage, but he stays—and that’s what matters.

I’ve also been lucky to meet the most incredible teachers. Cô Nga, thank you for always standing by my PhD dream. Cô Dung, for believing in my neuroscience journey, even when I dove in headfirst. Thầy Linh, Ethan, thầy Sơn, Ian, thầy Minh, thầy Quân, Matthew, Gareth, cô Lan—thank you for your patience and grace when I tried to solve problems in my own clumsy way. You all taught me that failure isn’t shameful—it’s a bridge.

Shoutout to my amazing research teammates—Nhi and chị Hảo, thank you for growing with me and helping our dream of publishing come true. And anh Rùa, thank you for saving me in my capstone. I couldn’t have made it without you.

To my girls—Minh Ngọc, Viên Nhi, Thảo Chi, Diệu Trang, Thục Anh—thank you for the love, laughs, and fierce support. I hope we all gather again—maybe at my wedding?

Ugh, I don’t want to grow up and grow away from Fulbright. It feels like waking up from the most beautiful dream… and facing a harsher world again. But Fulbright’s magic stays in me. Because of these years, I leave with a dream job, a scholarship to explore the U.S., and a heart ready to grow with the world. Fulbright turned what was supposed to be just a college experience into the most unforgettable chapter of my life.

column11:
At the heart of this journey, I believe that the person I am right now is shaped by so many fragments of my dearest friends and teachers and undeniably my family. My sciency version, genuine curiosity for life, and even life choice have been greatly inspired by the Integrated Sciences faculty, to whom I am forever in debt: cô Dung, cô Trang lớn, cô Trang bé, thầy Jesse, thầy Thiết, thầy Vân, cô Sam, and thầy Hùng. Because of them, I have been a learner and a thinker who will definitely spill the most useless facts about human physiology (like why you pee so much after an alcoholic drink) amidst a party. Without these people's support, I would not have the courage and determination to raise the standard for myself and pursue higher learning.
As I embrace the more humane part of me, my peers - my dear friends, colleagues, and mentors (anh/chị/bạn) have always been by my side. Thank you all for the random lab rants, Yakimono therapy sessions, late-night phone calls, and midnight support during sleepovers. You've taught me the most brainrot things ever while managing to be my strongest supporters for me and my intellectual journey.
To my parents – thank you for supporting me in every aspect of life, especially for each of my major decisions in life, even when you didn’t fully understand where they might take me. (Yes, I know you still call my major “Biotechnology” – and that’s okay).
When I look back, I realize this journey never truly started until I enrolled in the course "Algae" in my first year's summer semester. Visiting faculty thầy Thiết and thầy Vân not only taught me about algae but also changed my perspective on how the world we're living in works. I started to see the beauty in everything rather than meaning in everything as I imagined the complicated molecular machineries happening beyond my bare eyes. A fallen leaf, my mother's tears when I came out, and me being happy when I listen to Taylor Swift. Sometimes I wonder what if I hadn't decided to drop the course 2D/3D to enroll in Algae. Would I be adrift? Would I be masking my cluelessness with humor and convincing myself that life has a meaning and I had not yet found it (I blame late puberty)?
But while meaning is just an illusion we created to fool ourselves that our life is important, I found these 4 years of mine meaningful. In this long journey, I don't learn from "Fulbright"; I learn from people who happen to be present in my life, and somehow, some of them happen to be at Fulbright. And if there's only one thing I learnt from Scientific Inquiry, it would be the difference between causation and correlation.
As this chapter closes and I am still at the beginning of my life, I recall what thầy Thiết once shared: "Who you are is defined by the values you're willing to struggle for." And I am definitely willing to struggle just to understand a glimpse of this weird world we are living in.

So as I grew up, I stopped believing I'd ever have the chance to witness it. But here we are—1 AM at Half Moon Lake—watching meteors streak across the sky. It was so unexpected, yet so remarkable. I never thought I’d move to Ho Chi Minh City, let alone study at a five-year-old institution with its fair share of growing pains and dramas. "Là mình" ở đây ý chỉ mình tập trung lắng nghe để hiểu bản thân, tìm ra điều mình thích, là mình với phiên bản chân thành nhất trong cảm xúc, đam mê,... vì ở Fulbright là một môi trường đa dạng, ai cũng có những đam mê sở thích riêng, những sự ưu tú và nổi bật riêng, và cả những thành tựu riêng. Làm sao để giữa 1 cộng đồng như vậy, mình vẫn bình tĩnh với những giá trị của bản thân? Vẫn có quyền chọn lối đi riêng, vẫn được nhìn thế giới đầy hài hoà nhưng học trân trọng hơn những người bạn thật sự khiến mình thuộc về và vẫn bình tĩnh sống với điều mình chọn. Ở những ngày cuối đại học, mình có những bước đi sớm trong sự nghiệp cá nhân, và cả làm điều mình chưa từng nghĩ đó là làm capstone, nó cho mình được cảm nhận là mình rõ hơn bao giờ hết.

"Là người" là chọn được cộng đồng mình thuộc về, dành toàn phần tâm sức để thấu hiểu, để đồng cảm để chia sẻ, để thấu hiểu. Đôi khi giữa 1 công đồng đa dạng, lắng nghe và thấu hiểu cho mình cơ hội để kết nối nhiều hơn. Nhớ hồi dịch tụi mình chơi Haloween với nhau, rồi vào năm học thì đi nhặt rác ở Kiên Giang, Vũng Tàu, đi làm thiện nguyện ở Đắk Lắk hoặc rong ruổi các con phố Sài Gòn để làm cơm từ thiện. Mình được cùng những người khác, học về con người, về thiện nguyện, nhìn con người ở nhiều góc độ, và từ đó kêu gọi được nhiều người cùng đồng hành hơn, và hơn nữa những môn học ở Fulbright không chỉ dạy về kỹ thuật, kỹ năng, đó còn là hành trình quay lại những điều cơ bản nhất của con người, về văn hoá, về hành vi, về mong cầu,... 

"Là điều mình cống hiến". Mang CIDO trở thành Club of the Year, duy trì các thế hệ đều đặn và đông dần lên qua nhiều năm là điều đầu tiên mình luôn tự hào. Được làm nhiều công việc có ích cho xã hội là thứ hai. Luôn say hi, luôn mong cầu giúp đỡ, chia sẻ với những người bạn của mình là thứ ba. Đấy là những điều cống hiến đã tạo nên mình của hôm nay. Dẫu cho có nhiều mục tiêu về sự nghiệp khác nhưng những điều đó của bản thân tại Fulbright đã cho mình nhiều cảm hứng sống, để từng ngày đều là từng ngày ý nghĩa.

I came to Fulbright not knowing where I was headed — just a kid with a backpack full of questions and a heart half-curious, half-terrified. I remember my first day thinking, “What if I don’t belong?” Four years later, I can say this place didn’t just give me answers — it gave me the courage to ask louder, dream bolder, and fail better. From late-night deadlines to that one military campfire night where we all sang like we had nothing to lose — every moment made me feel alive and part of something bigger than myself. Thank you to every face I’ve met along the way. You were the reason there was always a way.

To my friends, who turned stress into laughter and deadlines into bonding time — I love you guys. To my professors, thank you for teaching me to unlearn as much as I learned.

The journey doesn’t end here — I’m aiming to build something meaningful, something that leaves the world a little more curious and a lot more kind.

And to Fulbright: I didn’t just graduate from you. I grew up with you.

column10:
I’m deeply grateful for the person I’ve become at Fulbright. Student Life here has been the best thing that ever happened to me. I’ll never forget our very first Orientation week—held online due to COVID-19—yet still so complete. Among all the sessions, the one that changed me the most was Boundary Setting. It shaped the way every Fulbright student treats others, and it continues to influence how I navigate relationships today.

From Residential Life to Wellness and Learning Support, try-out events to work-study programs—every experience has helped me grow, often even more than academic lectures. My first WSP, working as an IT Assistant, was especially transformative. I still remember the first time I met the IT staff, I nervously asked: “Will it be extremely embarrassing if someone asks a technical question and you don’t know the answer?” One of them simply said, “It’s normal.” That moment gave me the confidence to show up in class platforms, to fix things when I could, and to ask for help when I couldn’t.

That role opened the door to meeting so many faculty and staff members, forming relationships that turned into unforgettable memories—trips together, grabbing cá viên chiên in District 3, even staying in touch after they resigned. It also led me to become an AA Assistant, where I explored the behind-the-scenes world of university administration. It felt like a sandbox for my younger self, who once imagined growing up to be an "office worker."
column11:
The journey only truly began when we moved to offline learning in Spring 2022 and moved to the Waterfront. Living in shared dorms taught me how to embrace diversity, resolve conflicts, and accept that being different is not just okay—it’s valuable. I came into Fulbright as an 18-year-old still unsure of myself. But through my peers, I met the real me, and learn to embrace my unique values.

It was these amazing roommates who encouraged me to run for Student Council President in the AY23–24. I never imagined myself leading a team—I’d never done it before—but they believed in me. And their belief gave me the courage to believe in myself.

And then, there’s Running Club. A place where it doesn’t matter if I run slowly—or walk most of the time. The energy, the laughter, the encouragement from both friends and coaches made every run (and every walk) feel meaningful. Without them, the past few years could have felt dark and directionless. I always finished 21km right at the cut off time, yet they never make fun of me when I said I want to finish 42km before I graduate. I never thought I could become one who finds joy in running, but now, I am. And the motto we hold for running applies to every other achievement in life: take small steps, consistently.

It’s not about what I’ve achieved—but about the belief I now carry within me. Fulbright has given me the faith that, whatever comes my way, I’ll be ready to face it—and I’ll nail it.

column11:
Fulbright wasn’t where my college life started, but it’s where I finally got out of idle mode and into full operation. Transferring here felt like switching from closed-loop to open-loop control. suddenly, I had the freedom to explore, fail, recalibrate, and run wild. I was on the ground floor, running real-world tests with real machines, and real consequences.

Most of our projects were… let’s call them “nonlinear systems with unmeasurable disturbances.” Things overheated. Circuits fried. Hours of debugging. But every disaster added data to the feedback loop for better performance.

Outside the lab, I joined the Fulbright Ultimate Club, basically a dynamic system where friends act as both actuator and projectile. Great for cardio. Even better for learning real-time decision-making under high stress and humidity.

Now I’m leaving with shaky hands, burnt fingers, and a system memory full of well-earned errors. I came in as a student. I’m leaving as a high-risk, high-reward prototype, with fully tested, slightly unstable, and absolutely ready for deployment.

I paused, speechless, as a slow wave of melancholy washed over me, hinting that perhaps I was leaving this place soon. We spent so much time strolling around the lake. My fellow math friends would often join me after our thesis has grown tired of being written by us, and our Professor would treat the gang to ice cream. I even remember those slightly awkward practice sessions by the lake with my folks—singing away even as people passed by. These memories are the ones I’ve chosen to keep, even if my memory isn’t the best. Friends, I’m not sure how long this Yearbook will survive, but I’ll be a bit cheesy and say that I’m likely going to miss y’all.

To Bao Khang of 2021,

This is your future self writing to you, looking back on your college journey with awe and pride. You’d be amazed at how far you’ve come.

Do you remember when you first applied to Fulbright? One of the essay topics you chose was about Fear - fear of not being good enough, of doubting yourself. And yet, four years later, look at what you’ve achieved. You were once someone who rarely took the initiative, especially when it came to teamwork, one of your biggest challenges.

Back then, stepping out of my comfort zone seemed impossible. You hesitated to seek out opportunities. But now, looking back, you've built a path filled with growth and quiet victories. Who would’ve thought you'd end up leading a tennis community on campus, encouraging others to chase a green ball for hours with a racket? Or that you’d keep pushing forward, applying for jobs despite failures and uncertainties?

You’ve come a long way—from a hesitant high school student to a more grounded, emotionally mature young adult. Not only your thoughts but your perspective have changed through the experiences that you have encountered. Now, with just 34 days left at Fulbright, your time here is coming to a close. Graduation is just around the corner, and with it, a new chapter begins. There will be no more classes or campus life, but in its place comes the challenge yet excitement of standing on your own two feet. It’s intimidating, yes, but also full of possibility. 

Thank you, Fulbright, for being such an amazing part of my life. For giving me a place to meet incredible friends, mentors, and professors who have shaped me in ways I will always carry with me. This will forever remain one of the most meaningful chapters of my life.

I’ll see you soon, Khang. It’s time to move forward. Keep your head high, and just keep swimming. 

With love and pride,

Nguyễn Bảo Khang
(Graduated from Fulbright University Vietnam)

The high school me could’ve never imagined that freshman me would end up at Fulbright, pursuing professional filmmaking. Freshman me would’ve never guessed sophomore me would spontaneously declare an Integrated Sciences major after taking just one science class. Sophomore me would’ve been shocked to see junior me juggling three research projects and falling head over heels for the world of microorganisms. And junior me? She would’ve never believed that senior me would willingly take on math courses (despite struggling with them), complete a Capstone, and—most unexpectedly—get accepted into a solid PhD program in the U.S.
Both me and Fulbright have changed so much since the day we first met, but I am so glad that I allowed each and every event here that morphed me into the version of who I am today.

Looking back, my journey of Fulbright is indeed a rollercoaster, with many ups and downs. 
There were times of multiple personal crises when I felt completely lost—overwhelmed by a sense of directionlessness and meaninglessness. I used to be a diligent student, but then I neglected classes and assignment. I used to be determined and passionate, but I started missing deadlines and promises. In a panic, I kept myself as busy as possible, but deep down, I wasn’t sure what any of it was really for. 
Fortunately, I wasn’t alone on that journey—I was supported by friends, family, and mentors. Thanks to them, I found the light within myself to move forward. I learned to make peace with my past self. I learned to believe in my future self. And I learned to cherish the present.
I committed to rebuilding from simple things but I have forgot: eating 3 meals and sleep 7 hours a day, studying at library for better focus, not skipping classes, not missing assignments, and submitting work on time, mastering Outlook Calendar, taking notes and reviewing notes, attending office hours and events, reaching out and seeking help from departments, working out regularly, doing work study, internships, and research paper, joining Student Council, setting short-term and long-term goals. And most importantly, I managed to have fun with friends and enjoy life. 
I look forward to what’s next with hope and curiosity!

What I cherish the most at Fulbright is the deep community of acceptance. It’s not just about being surrounded by kind people — it’s about how we hold space for each other’s contradictions, complexities, and questions. There’s a culture here where differences aren’t just tolerated but embraced. Whether in a late-night dorm conversation, a community circle, or a heated classroom debate, I always felt like I belonged — not in spite of my individuality, but because of it.

Fulbright gave me not only the freedom to learn in my own way but the courage to unlearn, to be wrong, and to keep showing up. That, to me, is humans of Fulbright: real stories, real people, real growth.
column11:
When I first stepped into Fulbright, I wasn’t looking for answers — I was looking for permission to explore. And Fulbright gave me just that.

It didn’t mold me into a fixed shape. It gave me space to unfold.

The authentic learning culture encouraged me to try, fail, rethink, and design my own learning process. Professors didn’t just lecture — they listened. Classmates didn’t compete — they collaborated. I didn’t just study, I grew.

The diversity of thought here was not decorative, it was foundational. From anthropology to applied mathematics, from philosophy circles to activism workshops, I found myself navigating different ways of thinking and being. It reshaped how I approached knowledge — not as a trophy to claim, but a lens to question the world.

The collaborative spirit at Fulbright meant everything. No matter where you turned — the Library, Student Life, the classroom, even the Crescent Lake  — you’d find someone who’d walk beside you, share a laugh, or gently challenge your ideas.

Above all, it was the community of empathy that transformed me. Not just being heard, but being truly seen. Whether it was in a office hour, a community check-in, or a quiet look exchanged in a tough moment — I realized what a rare thing it is to feel both free and supported at once.

I will leave Fulbright not with a fixed identity, but a toolkit: to listen deeply, to collaborate across difference, to fail gracefully, to think with heart. I carry forward a belief in education as transformation, not transaction.

To those who are just beginning: don’t try to fit in. Be curious. Be weird. Be kind. Your journey will not look like anyone else’s — and that’s the point.

Thank you, Fulbright — for not shaping me, but for letting me shape myself.

It’s been such a great journey here. I still remember the time I submitted my Fulbright application — it was Spring cycle, 23:59, literally one minute before the deadline. Then came the interview round, and somehow, I made it. I became a Fulbright student.

My first semester was completely online. I made a few friends through online discussions and group projects, which felt weird at first, but somehow worked. When I found out we’d be moving to the dorms the next year, I was nervous but also excited to actually meet people in real life. And dorm life turned out to be amazing. I met so many great friends, especially my two roommates — Kyle and Khang Bi. I spent most of that first year at the Waterfront residence with them.

In our second year, we started making new friends from Docklands, and by the third year, six of us — Kyle, Phu, Khang, Tommy, and Luan — moved out together to River Panorama. That apartment became home. We made so many memories there.

I want to thank every single friend I’ve made — you’ve all given me some of the best, most unforgettable memories. And especially Kyle — I once said that all the money, time, and effort I spent here would be worth it just to meet him and become close friends. That still sums it up perfectly.

Also, huge thanks to my family — thank you for always being there and supporting me through everything.

And yeah, that’s pretty much it. I’ll leave the rest of this space for my favorite photos. For me, pictures don’t need to be 4K or anything fancy — as long as the people in them are happy, that’s all that really matters.

Một hành trình có thể nói là đầy đủ hỉ, nộ, ái, ố. Đến được Fulbright là mình đã đến được với nơi mình muốn đến, được học điều mình muốn học. Ở Fulbright, mình đã gặp được những người bạn tuyệt vời, cùng đi qua những ngày rực rỡ đến những khi mù sương.

column11:
Hành trình của mình với Fulbright sẽ luôn là câu chuyện được kể đi kể lại với những người bạn, người em, người đồng đội đồng hành của mình trong suốt cuộc đời khi nói về khoảng thời gian học đại học. Mình biết đến Fulbright nhờ cái duyên khi có cơ hội được nói chuyện với chị Hiền (Co24) khi 2 đứa đang là học sinh cấp 3. Mình biết yêu Fulbright khi nghe về câu chuyện thành lập, triết lý giáo dục và sứ mệnh đóng góp cho giáo dục Việt Nam, thấy giá trị mà bản thân mong muốn rất match với trường, mình dồn hết sức để apply vào và chinh phục trường bằng mọi giá. Rồi mình cũng từng tạm dừng và thậm chí muốn dừng luôn hành trình này khi gặp quá nhiều thử thách trong học tập, trong các mối quan hệ bạn bè, sự mông lung, vô định giữa dịch Covid trầm trọng ngay năm đầu tiên đến với Fulbright. Nhưng rồi sau tất cả, mình quyết định cho bản thân một cơ hội nữa để thử lại, mở rộng lòng hơn để đón nhận những trải nghiệm và thử thách “uncertainty” mà mình gặp phải, Co25 gặp phải và ngay cả trường cũng luôn phải đối mặt.

Nhân đây, mình cũng xin gửi lời cảm ơn sâu sắc đến tất cả những người bạn, người anh chị, thầy cô và các staff của trường đã đồng hành và hỗ trợ mình rất nhiều từ những ngày biết đến trường, apply, đậu, học, gap year, đến khi quay lại, bắt đầu lại rồi tốt nghiệp. Cảm ơn Minh Hiếu và chị Mã Y Vân đã là những người bạn đầu tiên đồng hành cùng em trong những ngày đầu quay lại Fulbright sau khi gap year. Cảm ơn Minh Hiếu vì đã mang CIDO đến với tao, giúp tao cởi mở và kết nối nhiều hơn với khóa Co25. And when I look back now, I realize that DST—the class I barely paid much attention to in the beginning—turned out to be the most impactful one. I learned that learning isn't just about the answers — it’s about the journey, the failures, the breakdowns, and the breakthroughs along the way. Through every lecture, group project, and late-night coding session, I’ve discovered more about my own limits, strengths, and passions.

As I move forward, I aim to continue embracing challenges head-on and applying what I’ve learned here — both academically and personally. The experiences, the friendships, and the lessons will continue to shape who I become.

The people — always the people.

Fulbright was the place where I met strangers who turned into teammates, friends, and sometimes heartbreaks. Some drifted in and out, some stuck around for a while, and a few stayed for good. But every single one left something with me — a lesson, a laugh, a late-night talk, a moment I didn’t know I’d hold onto.

Group projects were... something else. From smooth-sailing dream teams to chaotic messes that left me editing slides at 2AM — I weirdly loved it all. Even the worst projects ended with a shared meal and conversations that made me feel seen. That’s the magic of Fulbright: even when things go wrong, people show up.

I think most about those unexpected friendships — the ones that started with a random chat, a shared playlist, or just a feeling that we got each other. We were all so different, but somehow, it worked. Some of those friendships ended quietly, some painfully. But I’m thankful for every one of them.

column11:
It’s been a wild, beautiful, and unforgettable ride.

I didn’t have some grand plan when I applied to Fulbright. It was a spontaneous decision — my high school friends mentioned it, I googled it out of curiosity. “Liberal Arts”? “US-Vietnam relations”? I had no clue what those even meant. But as I scrolled through Fulbright’s website, something clicked. I pictured myself there. I clicked “Apply.”

That one impulsive moment brought me to a place that changed everything.

I entered Fulbright as a wide-eyed freshman, unsure of my English, emailing Learning Support just to ask for a slot in the Bridge Program. I wasn’t from a “gifted school,” hadn’t experienced international-style education — I felt lost, intimidated, and like I didn’t belong. I messaged strangers with “@fulbright.edu.vn” in their bios just to feel less alone.

Then, life started to happen. First friends, first classes, first late-night talks that spiraled into something more. I was overwhelmed — by the culture, the constant push for reflection, the discussions, the intellectual rush. I tried to keep up, but somewhere in the chaos, I lost a bit of myself.

It took time — and a lot of mistakes — to learn that I didn’t have to change who I was to thrive here. Sophomore year taught me how to slow down, to be patient with the process, to say “no” when something didn’t align with my values. I started choosing what mattered, not just what was impressive.

But Fulbright wasn’t all heavy. Some of my best memories live in Fulbright Event Hub, Fulbright Tennis, and The Luminous. I found joy in organizing, in leading, in building something with friends. The laughs, the stress, the breakthroughs, the tears — all of it stitched together something so real. Those moments will stay with me forever.

And somewhere along the way, Kyle. We started as classmates, then friends, and now — partners in every sense. We’ve studied, led the Tennis Club, rewritten our resumes a hundred times together. We’ve celebrated wins, survived losses, and stood by each other through it all. I’ll always be grateful to Fulbright for bringing us together.

Now, at the end of this four-year journey, I see someone different in the mirror. Someone who takes ownership of his life, who’s willing to take risks, fall down, and get back up again. Someone who dares to dream a little bigger.

I came in not knowing what Fulbright really was. Now, I leave knowing that Fulbright is a part of me. And I’ll always be proud to say: I’m a Fulbrighter.

For me to study at Fulbright, my parents made a significant sacrifice. That understanding has stayed with me from the very beginning, so when I moved to Saigon, I made a promise to myself: I would become financially independent as soon as possible to lessen the burden. From the first year, I threw myself into work. I worked relentlessly and achieved my goals. 

However, by the end of my third year, something hit me: I had lost what people often call "the college experience." I had no study group. No road trips with friends. No late-night heart-to-hearts. I hadn’t spent time with professors to truly explore ideas, or with classmates to build deep connections. I had missed out on the things that make college unforgettable. 

So I decided to open my heart—to people, to experiences. I paused the race up the corporate ladder and shifted my focus back to school. For the first time, I traveled to the beach with my friends. I pulled an all-nighter with a study group, cramming for an exam as the sun came up. I danced, played sports, stayed out late, laughed until I cried. For the first time, I felt like a real college student. 

I’m truly grateful for the people who walked into my life during this time. Friends who listened, who stayed, who supported me through every storm and celebrated every small joy. Professors who reminded me why I love to learn. And my parents, whose quiet sacrifices continue to be the foundation of everything I do.

Nơi đây đã và sẽ luôn là một ngôi nhà kỉ niệm của mình: nơi Quỳnh Phương được trải nghiệm sống với những người bạn từ xa lạ thành thân, nơi Quỳnh Phương được thử được sai và té ngã thật đau, nơi mình nhận ra dù có té đau thế nào thì vẫn luôn luôn có ai đó nói với mình rằng: "Không sao đâu, Piu đang làm tốt, Piu cố gắng mà",... và là nơi bắt đầu cho tất cả những hành trình khác. Fulbright là cái nôi của những sự bắt đầu trong Quỳnh Phương, nơi mình học để trở thành người bạn đối xử với chính mình bằng tình yêu thương và sự đón nhận, nơi mình học để chỉ quan tâm đến những điều thực sự quan trọng, là nơi mọi sự học về làm người và học về cuộc đời mới thực sự diễn ra. 
Cảm ơn cô ấy nhiều lắm vì dù nhiều thứ khó quá đi nhưng vẫn cứ thế mong cầu được trở thành một phiên bản nào đó hoàn thiện hơn của mình, dù chỉ là từng chút từng chút một. Viết đến đây làm mình lại trào lên một cảm xúc thương lắm cũng biết ơn và tự hào về mình lắm. Vì mỗi câu chuyện, mỗi bước chân đi, mỗi một ước nguyện và mỗi lần bước qua những thử thách của cuộc sống người lớn đều cho mình thấy mình thực tâm muốn trở thành người sống một cuộc đời ý nghĩa và có ích lắm. 
Cảm ơn Quỳnh Phương nhiều nhen, được đến đây là tốt lắm, tốt lắm rồi!

Saying that it was memorable is an understatement. I never inteneded to make friends at the start of university at all, and for 2.5 years... that was what happened: Moving through schoolwork while ignoring potential connections. Bascially, I was passing through like I never existed.

Things changed as I noticed how easy it was to connect with people in here. 

The turning point was when I attended Introduction to Video & Film Production in Spring 2023. I began to feel confident about sharing my ideas with other people, and so the last few years were extremely fun as I up the ante in many of my film and creative projects, trying to surpise/discomfort them as much as I can. Before I knew it, I had more friends than I could ever imagine.

Maybe I could have done this all along, but the more important lesson here is that I only need to focus on the future and its potential and don't let "what ifs" and regrets of the past slow you down as FUV's friendliness allows you to progress at your own pace. As long as I've gained something, the past was nothing.

I’m thankful for this journey and for the people who have walked it with me. column11:
“Voiceless” was the title of my entrance essay to Fulbright. It talked about the unheard stories of villains in fairy tales and how I empathize with them for being a misfit right in my own home. Bad versus evil, Ian must be glad that his teaching about “slave morality” touched me deeply. I started as a tempered high school kid trying to get myself out of the home where I felt misunderstood. Now, I find myself back in that same place, transforming both the love and pain into arts that I hold dear. I no longer want to purge the bad memories or cover them up with new ones. “Ethnographic gold,” chị Trâm would say, reminding me of how I can see through these bad memories and faded pain to learn more about my lineage. 

Now, I consider myself an intellectual nomad and an art practitioner who pays close attention to established institutions to pose questions about agency, identity, and phenomenology. Blending ethnographic works and art making, I see myself as a channeller, through which social forces materialize as visual patterns, sound waves, and words. In Bodies That Become Spatial (2024), a series of 30 low-exposure photographs, me and Hoang (my roommate) turned the Exit hall, a site where identities are suspended, into a workshop of meaning-making, spinning webs of light that stands in for the morphology of identities. In The Playgrounds (2025), a two-minute stereo audio mix, I cast myself in a self-made urban horror movie, grappling with the compressing adulthood in an exploitative neoliberal cityscape. Recently, with a new interest in making gastronomic reviews, I examined the aesthetics and taste of food reviewers including myself. Getting to know Michelin’s entangled history of being both a global gastronomic curator and a rubber baron with various plantations in Indochina, I wrote a preliminary research paper to explore how Michelin employs aesthetics and mystification to dissociate from its colonial history in Indochina, reframing its identity through the particular language of global culinary excellence.

column10: What I cherish most about Fulbright is the freedom to reinvent myself. It’s a place where there are no set paths, allowing me to explore new interests and redefine who I am. At Fulbright, I can be a scholar, an artist, or an activist without the pressure of fitting into one box. The freedom to fail has been key to this reinvention. Unlike traditional academic settings, where failure often feels like a setback, here it’s seen as part of the learning process. I’m encouraged to experiment and take risks without the fear of being judged. This has helped me grow academically and personally. Fulbright has allowed me to branch out beyond my original field of study, blending multiple disciplines that enrich my thinking. It’s given me the chance to explore different sides of myself—both as a student and as an individual. I’ve learned to embrace vulnerability, something I didn’t do before, and I’ve grown more open-minded and compassionate. Beyond academics, Fulbright has helped me understand my place in Vietnam and my role in the country’s future. It’s a space where I can challenge ideas, reflect on my identity, and contribute to a larger conversation about the world. The autonomy to shape my own education has been empowering. Fulbright doesn’t just offer a rigid curriculum; I’ve been able to pursue what excites me and take ownership of my learning. This flexibility has been crucial in my personal growth.
column11:
I can still remember the first day I stepped onto the Fulbright campus: excited, nervous, and maybe just a little bit overwhelmed. I was stepping into an environment that was totally new to me. But as soon as I walked through the doors, I felt something different. It wasn’t just the beautiful campus or the impressive facilities, it was the energy. The energy of people who were as excited to learn and explore as I was, people who weren’t afraid to challenge ideas and push boundaries.

When I first came to Fulbright, I thought I knew exactly what I wanted. I had my major, my goals, my expectations. But what I didn’t know was that Fulbright would change everything. It’s here that I learned how to reinvent myself. I started with one set of ideas, but I’ve evolved so much since then, academically, personally, and creatively. Fulbright gave me the space to try things I never would have attempted before. To explore new passions, meet people from different walks of life, and dive into fields I never thought would interest me. It pushed me to be a better version of myself, more confident, more open-minded, and more willing to embrace change and uncertainty.

There were moments, of course, when I doubted myself. Moments when I questioned my path or wondered if I was making the right choices. But those moments were part of the process. Fulbright never told me to have all the answers right away. Instead, it encouraged me to explore, to fail, to learn, and to grow at my own pace. And in the end, those doubts became my greatest teachers.

The friendships I’ve formed here have been another highlight. Fulbright is full of people who challenge you, who inspire you, and who help you become the best version of yourself. I’ll never forget the late-night conversations with friends and professors, where we debated everything from politics to art to the meaning of life itself. These moments, these connections, have shaped me in ways I’ll carry with me forever.

As I think about the future, I can’t help but feel excited. I have so many ideas, so many dreams, and I know that Fulbright has given me the tools and confidence to make them a reality. My time here has shown me that my journey is just beginning and that I don’t need to have it all figured out right now. What matters is that I keep moving forward with curiosity, with passion, and with the courage to follow my own path.

A huge thank you to everyone who made this experience unforgettable. To my professors who pushed me to think beyond the obvious, to my friends who made every day an adventure, and to Fulbright for being the kind of place where reinvention is not just allowed but encouraged.

These All-Nighters Made Me

My college nights split into two chapters.

The first: nights out with my people—at The Waterfront, Docklands, anywhere we could just be. We were young, curious, a little wild. Those nights were filled with laughter, stories, tears, spontaneous drinking in Japanese town, clubbing till we crashed, wandering the residence halls just to feel something real. We shared everything—secrets, silence, sadness, joy. I met strangers who became friends, and friends who became memories. I made choices I celebrated and mistakes I had to sit with. But through it all, I learned. I grew. I’ll never forget those nights.

The second chapter: the study nights. The real, raw ones. The anxious cramming, the silent breakdowns, the Red Bulls and Monsters lined up on my desk like soldiers. The instant noodles at midnight, the endless loop of lo-fi beats. I used to hate exams—still kind of do—but somehow, I survived every one. I mastered the art of the all-nighter. Somewhere along the way, I stopped panicking and started trusting myself.
To everyone who was part of this chaos—my housemates, study buddies, 3AM Zoom crew, my cheat sheets and most importantly, my grades—thank you. You were part of it all.

These nights made me who I am. And no matter how much time passes, I’ll always remember them.

To the staff, past and present, I want you to know how much your work has meant to me and to all of us. The check-ins, the support emails, the behind-the-scenes work you never asked credit for, the way you remembered our names and asked how we were doing, even during the busiest times. It’s hard to put into words how comforting it is to feel genuinely cared for in a space that could’ve easily been just another institution. You gave it heart.

But I truly believe that each of you, in your own way, in your own capacity, has done your best to steer this ship through so many storms. Especially to the Admissions team (and I say this with deep love and immense gratitude), thank you for letting me be a part of your world for the past four years. I want to be clear that I deeply cherish every department in this school, and I hope the rest of you will forgive me for singling one out. But working with Admissions was something truly special. I’ve learned so much, not just about outreach or selection, but about people, about kindness, about stories, and about the quiet, powerful impact of believing in someone before they even believe in themselves.

There’s no single memory that sums it all up. It’s the little things that linger: the way someone held the elevator door, the messages during Capstone madness, or the quiet comfort of walking into a room full of people who somehow, despite all our differences, understood what this journey meant. Fulbright gave me a thousand tiny memories that, stitched together, made something I’ll hold onto forever.

So if this is the last letter I get to write here, let it be a thank you. A quiet, sincere, full-hearted thank you. I’m leaving, but I’ll always carry this place, and all of you, with me.

With love,

During my four years at Fulbright, I’ve had both good and bad memories—but I cherish them all, as they’ve shaped who I am today. Among them, the military training course (MTC) stands out as the most beautiful and emotionally truthful experience I’ve had.

There are two main reasons for this. First, MTC reminded me of my high school days. Unlike university life, where everyone is caught up in their own hustle, MTC placed us all in the same routine, same conditions, and same goal—making it out alive. Like high school, we studied, ate, and slept together. In that uniform setting, the only personal things we had were our emotions and relationships. With nothing else to distract us, we had all the time in the world to care for one another.

Second, the intensity of the training pushed us to find joy in the simplest, most organic ways. On the first day, I expected to keep to myself and get through it quietly. But the harsh summer heat and physical challenges brought us closer. We shared fans, food, jokes, drinks—and even moments of lying on the floor half-naked just to cool down. We supported each other through every chore and challenge, without conflict, because we knew we were all in the same boat.

It felt like rediscovering childhood with people my age—playing, singing, and bonding like kids again. It was rare, raw, and something I’ll carry with me for a long time.

I come from a mountainous region where access to higher education was a distant dream. This journey at Fulbright, which began in a small, remote village, has transformed me in ways I once only dared to imagine. My time at Fulbright is a tapestry woven with hardship, discovery, and triumph.

In my hometown, resources were scarce, and expectations were modest. Education was valued, but opportunities were limited. The decision to leave my mountainous home and venture to Saigon was both exhilarating and terrifying. Saigon, with its bustling energy and modern allure, was a stark contrast to my quiet, rugged upbringing. I arrived with a mix of excitement and apprehension, unsure if I would fit in or if I was even capable of achieving what many deemed impossible.

Studying at Fulbright was a turning point - a validation that my potential was recognized beyond the boundaries of my humble beginnings. It opened doors not just to academic excellence, but also to a world of experiences that I had never imagined I would encounter. At Fulbright, I was not just a student; I was a creator, a performer, a researcher, and ultimately, a person in the making.

Perhaps the most transformative aspect of my time at Fulbright was the community I found here. My classmates and professors came from diverse backgrounds, each bringing their own unique perspectives to the table. Our differences were not barriers—they were bridges that connected us. In group projects, late-night study sessions, and spontaneous discussions about life and dreams, I discovered the power of collaboration and empathy. I made friends who challenged me to grow, who celebrated my successes, and who held my hand during moments of doubt. The support and understanding I received were beyond what I could have ever hoped for.

I learned to trust my instincts, to stand firm in my decisions, and to embrace the uncertainty of the future with open arms. Every setback was a lesson, every failure a testament to my resilience, and every success a glimpse of the person I was becoming.

The most profound impact of my Fulbright experience is how it reshaped my understanding of purpose. Coming from a normal background, I had always dreamed of a future where I could transcend the limitations imposed by my circumstances. Fulbright not only provided me with the education to pursue that dream—it instilled in me the confidence to believe that I could make a meaningful impact in the world. With my newfound skills and experiences, I was able to secure a job aligned with my passion for music—an area I had always loved but never imagined could be a viable career. This opportunity, born out of chance and nurtured by hard work, has given me the confidence to face every decision with a sense of purpose and determination.

column9: At Fulbright, I didn’t just step out of my comfort zone — I leapt. And in that leap, I found resilience, purpose, and the courage to grow.
column10:
I still vividly remember my first day at Fulbright — which was also the very first day of my first semester. I had two classes that day and was excited to arrive on time, eager to meet my professors and classmates.
Strangely enough, it was also my first time stepping foot on the Crescent campus. I didn’t know how to enter the buildings or where the classrooms were. I was too embarrassed to ask anyone, thinking to myself, “How can I be a student here and not even know where my classes are?”
I still smile at those early moments — the awkwardness, the embarrassment of my first wrong answer, and even the first time I called a professor by their first name without realizing it. But those moments quickly passed. From the very beginning, I was surrounded by kind friends, peer mentors, and supportive instructors.
I’m deeply grateful to have studied at Fulbright and to have grown in such a heartwarming environment that allowed me to make mistakes, learn from them, and build the courage to step outside of my comfort zone.
President Scott once shared that one of the guiding principles of our university is to create a safe and supportive space where students are encouraged to speak up, take initiative, and continuously grow. Thank you for saying it — and thank you, Fulbright, for truly living it.
Because over these past four years, I’ve felt it deeply: I’ve been embraced, nurtured, and empowered to become the best version of myself.
column11:
As you can see on this page, my memories with Fulbright are also deeply tied to my time with the Fulbright Ultimate Club (FUC), our ultimate frisbee team. Over the past four years, I’ve laughed, cried, pushed through pain and bitterness, and received so much love from our coaches and teammates.
My journey with FUC has been far more than just athletic training — it’s been a journey of stepping out of my comfort zone, building resilience, and learning how to love, care for, encourage, and inspire others like a true family.
Through FUC and frisbee, I’ve traveled across Vietnam and even to other countries for tournaments. We’ve shared victories, earned medals, and made memories that I’ll carry for life.
And deep down, I know that all the love and memories we’ve shared could only have happened here — at Fulbright.
Fulbright is a place where inclusiveness, diversity, and equality are truly cherished. It’s where students are lifted up, where we’re given a safe and empowering environment to pursue our dreams — even the wildest ones.
